ai-mn76:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-mn76:2.1_0: Now at that time the wanderer Sandaka was residing at the cave of the wavy leaf fig tree together with a large assembly of around five hundred wanderers.
ai-mn76:3.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn76:3.2_0: “Come, reverends, let’s go to the Devakata Pool to see the cave.”
ai-mn76:3.4_0: Then Ānanda together with several mendicants went to the Devakata Pool.
ai-mn76:4.1_0: Now at that time, Sandaka and the large assembly of wanderers were sitting together making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of unworthy talk, such as
ai-mn76:4.2_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-mn76:4.3_0: Sandaka saw Ānanda coming off in the distance,
ai-mn76:4.5_0: “Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound.
ai-mn76:4.6_0: The ascetic Ānanda, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.
ai-mn76:4.7_0: He is included among the disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Kosambī.
ai-mn76:4.8_0: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
ai-mn76:4.9_0: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
ai-mn76:5.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the wanderer Sandaka,
ai-mn76:5.4_0: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
ai-mn76:5.5_0: Please, Ānanda, sit down, this seat is ready.”
ai-mn76:5.6_0: Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-mn76:5.7_0: while Sandaka took a low seat and sat to one side.
ai-mn76:5.9_0: “Sandaka, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
ai-mn76:5.10_0: “Master Ānanda, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
ai-mn76:5.11_0: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
ai-mn76:5.12_0: May Master Ānanda himself please clarify the Dhamma.”
ai-mn76:5.13_0: “Well then, Sandaka, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn76:6.1_0: “Sandaka, these four ways that have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t complete the procedure of the skillful teaching.”
ai-mn76:6.2_0: “But Master Ānanda, what are the four ways that negate the spiritual life, and the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
ai-mn76:7.1_0: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
ai-mn76:7.2_0: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
ai-mn76:7.3_0: This person is made up of the four primary elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
ai-mn76:7.4_0: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
ai-mn76:7.5_0: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.
ai-mn76:7.7_0: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
ai-mn76:7.8_0: Giving is a doctrine for morons.
ai-mn76:7.9_0: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
ai-mn76:7.10_0: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and they don’t exist after death.’

ai-mn76:10.5_0: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
ai-mn76:10.6_0: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

ai-mn76:35-42.1_0: “Sandaka, it’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. ...

ai-mn76:35-42.4_0: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability lead the spiritual life under a teacher who achieves such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the procedure of the skillful teaching.

ai-mn76:48.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
ai-mn76:48.2_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place.

ai-mn76:48.3_0: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability lead the spiritual life under a teacher who achieves such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the procedure of the skillful teaching.
ai-mn76:49.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-mn76:49.2_0: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-mn76:49.3_0: He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
ai-mn76:50.1_0: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-mn76:50.2_0: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
ai-mn76:50.3_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-mn76:50.4_0: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability lead the spiritual life under a teacher who achieves such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the procedure of the skillful teaching.”
ai-mn76:51.1_0: “But Master Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—could they still enjoy sensual pleasures?”
ai-mn76:51.2_0: “Sandaka, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.
ai-mn76:51.3_0: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a lay person.
ai-mn76:51.4_0: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these five respects.”
ai-mn76:52.1_0: “But Master Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected, would the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended be constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?”
ai-mn76:52.3_0: “Well then, Sandaka, I shall give you a simile.
ai-mn76:52.4_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-mn76:52.5_0: Suppose there was a person whose hands and feet had been amputated.
ai-mn76:52.6_0: Would they be aware that their hands and feet had been amputated constantly and continually, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?
ai-mn76:52.7_0: Or would they be aware of it only when they checked it?”
ai-mn76:52.8_0: ‘May I have handed over with my hands?’”
ai-mn76:52.9_0: “They wouldn’t be aware of it constantly,
ai-mn76:52.10_0: ‘May I have handed over my hands.’
ai-mn76:52.12_0: ‘May my hands and feet be in my hands’?”
ai-mn76:52.13_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant is perfected, the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended is not constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.
ai-mn76:53.1_0: “But Reverend Ānanda, how many emancipators are there in this teaching and training?”
ai-mn76:53.2_0: “There are not just one hundred emancipators, Sandaka, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that in this teaching and training.”
ai-mn76:53.3_0: He said, “It’s incredible, Master Ānanda, it’s amazing.
ai-mn76:53.4_0: Namely, that there’s no glorifying one’s own teaching and putting down the teaching of others. The Dhamma is taught in its own field, and so many emancipators are recognized.
ai-mn76:53.5_0: But these Ājīvaka ascetics, those sons of dead sons, glorify themselves and put others down. And they only recognize three emancipators:
ai-mn76:53.6_0: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and Makkhali Gosāla.”
ai-mn76:54.1_0: Then the wanderer Sandaka addressed his own assembly,
ai-mn76:54.2_0: “Go, good sirs. The spiritual life is lived under the ascetic Gotama.
ai-mn76:54.3_0: It’s not easy for me to give up possessions, honor, or popularity now.”
ai-mn76:54.4_0: And that’s how the wanderer Sandaka sent his own assembly to lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.
ai-mn76:54.5_0: The sixth section on Sandaka is finished.
